comments.commentBody: The commentator is out of touch with contemporary Cuba. Had he recently visited Cuba he would find a country of well educated and politically aware people, most of whom are more than willing to voice their political views, including negative views on the government's missteps.  Criticism seems to be part of Cuban DNA.  There are major material deprivations in Cuba and that is why Cubans risk so much to come to the US-- nothing to do with political repression.

But Melvin, how will the solution come from inside when Cubans do not have free election, a free press, the right to demonstrate, etc. How does change come about in such a repressive regime? If you protest in Cuba and agitate for change you are incarcerated as a "counter-revolutionary". Don't you think international outside pressure on Cuba might help as it did in South Africa?
I don't think Marco Rubio was born in Cuba.

So the absence of US investment is all Cuba needs? You're living in a fantasy world. Cuba and Cubans have way more serious issues than your comment insinuates, most of which the embargo wouldn't solve. Foreign countries are free to invest and trade, yet that doesn't seem to have helped. So what else is going on with Cuba?

I wish they would get rid of the embargo just so I don't have to hear this nonsense every time Cuba is brought up.

and what about those who are not criminals? who left so that they could support their families? have you been in that situation? did you grow up on $12 a month? or with minimal access to healthcare due to limited funds? you speak of suffering and sending them back I encourage you to live there and then make a comment like that.

That is an amazing amount of backwards reasoning to put into a single posting.

Of course tax revenues are up. The economy and businesses are doing better. You do not owe any taxes if you do not make money. What rational business would prefer to see their business fail just to avoid paying taxes?

What "cracks" in the ACA? Are you talking about the gaping holes ripped in the law by Republicans that refused to implement the Medicaid expansion?

Health insurance premiums are rising at the lowest rate in a generation thanks to the ACA act. If you feel they are beyond reason just image where they would be if we hadn't taken action.

"So we can cheer the government for taxing business enough to pay for its still-enormous spending."

No, we can thank the Obama administration for rejecting GOP policies that would do nothing but line the pockets of the wealthy, and instead adopted polices that created millions of jobs which allowed people to spend to earn money to spend at the businesses that pay taxes.

The people who replied so negatively to my Comment, apparently don't care about families that have exhausted their assets having to pay enormously-increased premiums, and where the insurance is no longer allowed even to pay for life-saving drugs for a child.
These children could soon die, and because of the new ACA law you say is so wonderful. I could look up the article where I read about this, if you demand proof.
As for all those you say used to 'fall through the cracks', there were no cracks anyway that they had to fall through. They simply had no insurance, and that was that. If they still don't, nothing's changed ...except hospitals now are sometimes denying needed medical aid, just because they now think people can or should be covered by the new ACA law.
So things are worse medically for a majority of people now perhaps? Try to prove it isn't.

Deficits are down, and the explanation is mostly in the fact that tax revenues have been rising. So we can cheer the government for taxing business enough to pay for its still-enormous spending.
But can this kind of prosperity continue? There are those who say disaster looms on the horizon. And then there are the Pollyannas.

Dr. Krugman paints again a rosy picture of the new Affordable Care Act. " ... many people ... — have the impression that the rollout of Obamacare has been a disaster, and have no idea that enrollment is above expectations, costs are lower than expected, and the number of Americans without insurance has dropped sharply."
Have these people read about all the people who have fallen 'through the cracks' in healthcare as it has come to be, after the A.C.A. was set loose on the nation?

Do they understand how premiums have gone beyond reason, beyond ability for many yet to pay them, for many people who previously were helped greatly by the healthcare system as it was before?
They have fallen through the cracks that absolutely had not existed, before the sorry effects set in, of the new monstrous health law.

'United We Stand', an independent political campaign slogan in the early 90s, has also long gone out the window.  The first word noted. missing after the election of the President in 2008 was 'Bipartisan', leaving this American voter mystified.

Citizens United reminds us of an ugly part of our American past.  We don't like to be reminded of our nations good old days that were really very bad. American free enterprise system invented lots of things and one of them was Robber Barons. Or, that the real truth about America is that it and its implied freedoms can be bought for a price.  These are the ugly truths that we hold self evident.

This is the first comment I've seen on this blog to address the idea of group homes.  They are a wonderful alternative for folks who cannot afford, and do not need, a nursing home.  My dad has some stable dementia, a feeding tube, insulin-dependent diabetes, and is non-ambulatory.  He needs help with all basic needs.  And yet he is served very well in a group home in AZ.  There is the advantage of a small staff who gets to know residents personally.  And a good one will allow unannounced visits at any time of day, so monitoring is not hard to do.  My dad, at 91, has been healthy and happy there.

Dr. Krugman:
Thanks to your regular reminders in your columns, ever since President Obama was sworn in, I've been monitoring the numbers.
Mainly, I was interested to see how Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner was going to lift this bloated giant out of the canyon it created.
Little by little, very slowly and gently, the U.S. super ship righted itself and balanced.
Things aren't perfect, but there has been perceptible improvement on a regular basis over time.
It's been amazing to watch progress.
And success should principally be credited to President Obama and his administration and accomplished by the business sector.
Sometimes progress has been glaringly uneven.
We witness gigantic income disparity throughout the economy.
As someone on CNBC said recently, we really have a two-tiered economy: Wall Street and Main Street.
And our goals conflict.
My husband and I are Main Streeters, now retired.
How dare these deficit hawks call us "takers"?
We have earned every penny of retirement income we receive.
Yes, we ARE entitled.
If they mess with our retirement, its theft.
That's what these idiots don't understand.
In their ignorance, they have caused a giant rent in the fabric of the nation.
Time to get out the needle and thread (Congress, where are you?) and start sewing, even as we deal with ISIS/ISIL, ebola and the loss of leadership in the Secret Service.
The administration is working hard; where is Congress?
My 2 cents.

Dr. Krugman has again hit the nail on the head, especially about the mistaken but prevalent belief that deficits are bad and worsening under Obama. After all, isn't that what the whole Tea Party movement is about, government spending and deficits out of control? All those people wouldn't get dressed up and have conventions if there weren't a problem, would they? So TP'ers get all the press, and the facts are lost as background noise.

James, you're mistaking deficit with debt. The national debt is what we owe in total. The deficit (or surplus - we had those in the Clinton administration) is the change in the debt over a year. For math geeks it's the first temporal derivative of the debt.

As Krugman alluded, the meaningful number is debt divided by GDP, or for one year the deficit divided by GDP. If the deficit for fiscal 2014 was 2.8 percent of GDP, and if during the same time the GDP was growing at 2.8 percent per year, then effectively, in real value terms, we have no deficit. In that instance the economy would be growing fast enough to offset the actual value of what we borrowed.

And curiously, Kiplinger is predicting a 3.5 percent growth in GDP for the most recent quarter, and 3.0 percent going forward.
